questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding bladder injury?

choices.text: Intraperitoneal bladder injuries can be managed with catheter drainage for 7-10 days.
Pelvic urinoma is seen in intraperitoneal rupture.
A CT cystogram enables the clinical diagnosis for bladder injury and urinary extravasation.

questions.solution:
In bladder injury and urinary extravasation, a computed tomography (CT) cystogram is the diagnostic procedure of choice.

Bladder rupture

  Intraperitoneal rupture Extraperitoneal rupture
  Less common (20%) More common (80%)
Cause
  • Blow or fall on a distended bladder
  • Surgical damage (rare)
  • Blunt trauma
  • Surgical damage
Clinical features
  • Sudden severe pain in the hypogastrium
  • Syncope
  • Peritonitis
  • Pelvic urinoma (encapsulated collection of extravasated urine) is seen
Treatment
  • Laparotomy
  • Repair of bladder
  • Bladder drainage
     • Catheter drainage for 7–10 days

questions.text: Which of the following is not a first-generation cephalosporin?
questions.solution:
Cefaclor is not a first-generation cephalosporin. It is a second-generation oral cephalosporin.

First-generation cephalosporins are :

  • Oral formulation
    • Cefadroxil
    • Cephalexin
    • Cephradine
  • Parenteral formulation - cefazolin

Related Pearl: Classification of cephalosporins

First-generation cephalosporins
Parenteral Oral
Cefazolin Cephalexin
Cefadroxil

 

Second-generation cephalosporins
Parenteral Oral
Cefuroxime
Cefoxitin		 Cefaclor
Cefuroxime axetil
Cefprozil

 

Third-generation cephalosporins
Parenteral Oral
Cefotaxime
Ceftizoxime
Ceftriaxone
Ceftazidime (Antipseudomonal)
Cefoperazone

Cefixime
Cefpodoxime
Cefdinir
Ceftibuten
Ceftamet 

 

Fourth-generation cephalosporins
Parenteral Oral
Cefepime (Antipseudomonal)
Cefpirome		    ---

 

Fifth-generation cephalosporins
Parenteral (Anti-MRSA activity) Oral
Ceftaroline
Ceftobiprole

questions.text: What is the minimum external pressure that leads to the formation of pressure sores?
questions.solution:
The minimum external pressure that leads to the formation of pressure sores is 30 mm of Hg.

Pressure sores also known as bedsores, pressure ulcers, or decubitus ulcers are defined as tissue necrosis with ulceration due to prolonged pressure. When the external pressure exceeds the capillary occlusive pressure, blood flow ceases leading to tissue anoxia, necrosis, and ulceration. Thus an external pressure of >30mmHg leads to the formation of pressure sores.

The common sites of pressure sores in decreasing frequency are:

  • Ischium
  • Greater Trochanter
  • Sacrum
  • Heel
  • Malleolus (lateral followed by medial)
  • Occiput

A staging system for the description of pressure sores devised by the American National Pressure Ulcer Advisory Panel.

Stage 1 - Non-blanchable erythema without a breach in the epidermis
Stage 2 - Partial-thickness skin loss involving the epidermis and dermis
Stage 3 - Full-thickness skin loss extending into the subcutaneous tissue but not through underlying fascia
Stage 4 - Full-thickness skin loss through fascia with extensive tissue destruction, maybe involving muscle, bone, tendon, or joint

Prevention is the best treatment for pressure sores. It can be done through good skincare, the use of air-fluidized beds, special pressure dispersion cushions, or foams. The position of the bedridden patients should be changed once every 2 hours and wheel-chair bound patients should be taught to get off their chairs for 10 seconds every 10 minutes.

Surgical treatment of pressure sores mainly involves wound management. The pressure sores should be adequately debrided and vacuum-assisted closure (VAC).VAC is done by applying intermittent negative pressure of approximately -125mmHg to hasten debridement and promote granulation tissue formation in chronic wounds and ulcers. Negative pressure decreases edema, removes interstitial fluid, and increases blood flow. This decreases bacterial growth and increases cell proliferation.

Large skin flaps that have muscle with sensory innervation are best for reconstruction(example-extensor fascia lata flap with the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh). Faecal or urinary diversion can be considered in special cases depending on the site of the ulcer, being prone to urine or faecal contamination.

Related Pearl: Staging of Pressure Sores

 

Stage

Description
1 Non-blanchable erythema without a breach in the epidermis
2

Partial thickness skin loss involving the epidermis and dermis
3

Full thickness skin loss extending into the subcutaneous tissue but not through underlying fascia
4 Full thickness skin loss through fascia with extensive tissue destruction, maybe involving muscle, bone, tendon or joint

questions.text: The SA Node acts as the pacemaker of the heart because, it ____.
questions.solution: The SA node acts as the pacemaker of the heart as it generates impulses at the highest rate (70-80/min), compared to AV node (40-60/min) and Purkinje fibres (15-40). The impulses generated by SA node are conducted through AV node and purkinje fibres repetedly that it will prevent AV node or Purkinje fibres reach their own thresholds for self-excitation.

questions.text: The accepted minimum period of sexual cohabitation resulting in no offspring for a couple to be declared infertile is ______
questions.solution:
The accepted minimum period of sexual cohabitation resulting in no offspring for a couple to be declared infertile is One Year.

  • Infertility implies apparent failure of a couple to conceive, while sterility indicates absolute inability to conceive, for one or more reasons.
  • If a couple fails to achieve pregnancy after 1 year of ‘unprotected’ and regular intercourse, it is an indication to investigate the couple.

Infertility is of two types:

  • Primary infertility: When no previous pregnancies have occurred.
  • Secondary infertility: When a prior pregnancy (although not necessarily a live birth) has occurred.

questions.text: You are doing an emergency laparotomy for a case of intestinal obstruction. Which organ will you first visualize to know if this is a case of small bowel or large bowel obstruction?
questions.solution:
The cecum is the first organ to be visualized to differentiate between the small and large bowel in cases of intestinal obstruction.

Distension of the cecum will confirm large bowel involvement. The identification of a collapsed distal segment of the large bowel and its sequential proximal assessment will lead to the identification of the cause.

questions.text: Which of the following types of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) has the worst prognosis?
questions.solution:
Collecting duct renal cell carcinoma has the worst prognosis of all renal cell carcinoma subtypes.

The renal cell carcinoma subtypes with poor prognosis in descending order are:

  • Collecting duct renal cell carcinoma
  • Medullary renal cell carcinoma
  • Clear cell renal cell carcinoma

Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma has the best prognosis.

questions.text: The most common functioning tumor of the pituitary is _______
questions.solution:
PRL-secreting adenoma or prolactinoma is the most common functioning tumor of the pituitary.

Increased prolactin levels cause irregular menstrual periods or no menstrual periods, milky discharge from the breasts when not pregnant or breast-feeding, painful intercourse due to vaginal dryness, acne, and excessive body and facial hair growth.

questions.text: Pathognomonic sign of dermatomyositis is
questions.solution:
Pathognomonic sign of dermatomyositis is Gottron's papules. They are erythematous to violaceous papules that occur symmetrically over extensor aspects of metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints.

Gottron's sign, on the other hand, is erythematous rash over the extensor surfaces of joints such as the knuckles, elbows, knees, and ankles. 

Note-

Gottron's papules and heliotrope rash are both pathognomonic signs of dermatomyositis.

questions.text: The wound in the given image is most likely to have been produced by?
questions.solution:
The image shows 'tram-line' bruising, most likely to have been produced by a stick or a broom handle. 

Tram-line bruising:

  • When the skin surface is struck by a rod or rectangular sectioned object such as a cane or lath, the consequent bruising may be of the ‘tram-line’ or ‘railway line’ type.
  • The mechanism of this double line is that the weapon sinks into the skin on impact so that the edges drag the skin downwards and the traction tears the marginal blood vessels. The centre compresses the skin, which, in the absence of underlying bone, causes little or no damage to the vessels.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common disease after a disaster?
questions.solution:
Gastroenteritis is the most commonly reported disease after a disaster. 

It occurs due to contamination of water supply, damage to the sewerage system, overcrowding and poor sanitation. Therefore, supply of safe drinking water and proper disposal of excreta are the most practical and effective strategies of disease prevention in the post–disaster period.

questions.text: The usage of iodized salt advocated by iodine deficiency control programmes in endemic areas is _______
questions.solution:
The usage of iodized salt in iodine deficiency advocated by iodine deficiency control programmes in endemic areas is part of primary prevention as it provides specific protection.

Global Iodine Deficiency Disorders Prevention Day is observed every year on 21st October to raise awareness about the fair use of iodine, to highlight the factors that lead to iodine deficiency and its consequences. Iodine deficiency disorders are the world’s most prevalent yet easily preventable.

Related Pearl: Levels of Prevention

Level

Primordial

Primary

Secondary

Tertiary

Phase of disease

Underlying socio-economic & environmental conditions leading to causation

Specific causal or risk factors

Early stage of disease

Late stage of disease

Aim

Establish and maintain conditions that minimize hazards to health

Reduce the incidence of disease

Reduce prevalence by shortening duration

Reduce number and impact of complications

Actions

Inhibition of emergence of socio-economic, environmental and behavioural conditions

Protection of personal and community health by eliminating risks

Early detection and intervention to minimize disability

Soften the impact of long-term disease and disability, minimize suffering

Modes of Intervention

Health education

Health promotion and specific protection

 

Diagnosis and treatment

Disability limitation and rehabilitation

Targets

Total population or select groups

Total population or high risk individuals/groups

 

Individuals/ Patients

Patients

questions.text: Tc HMPAO SPECT is used for:
questions.solution:
• Tc HMPAO SPECT is used for cerebral perfusion assessment. For example, in Alzheimer's it shows reduced perfusion of the temporoparietal region.
  • D-SPECT represents the next step in the evolution of SPECT technology and is based on a unique acquisition geometry. It has nine arrays of cadmium zinc telluride (CZT) detectors, each of which rotates around its central axis with programmable angular rotation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a barrier penetrated by the sperm in the ovum?
questions.solution:
The sperm does not penetrate the nuclear membrane of the ooctye.

The three barriers form sperm penetration in the ovum include:

  • Corona radiata
  • Zona pellucida
  • Oocyte cell membrane 

After the fusion of the sperm and oocyte cell membranes, the nucleus of the ovum is converted to the female pronucleus, and the nucleus of the sperm becomes the male pronucleus.

questions.text: A patient has developed confusion and keeps bumping into objects. He can speak fluently. But on examination, he cannot differentiate between fingers and cannot write. He also gets confused with the examiner's right and left sides. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis for this patient is Gerstmann syndrome. It is commonly associated with damage to the left (dominant) inferior parietal lobule.

Gerstmann syndrome consists of:

  • Acalculia - impairment of simple arithmetic
  • Dysgraphia - impaired writing
  • Finger anomia - an inability to name individual fingers 
  • Right-left confusion - an inability to tell whether a hand, foot, or arm of the patient or examiner is on the right or left side of the body

Option B: Anton syndrome also known as visual anosognosia occurs due to bilateral infarction in the distal PCAs. It produces cortical blindness and the patients are unaware of the blindness or may even deny it.

Option C: Millard-Gubler syndrome occurs due to ventral pontine injury. It causes functional loss of the 6th and 7th cranial nerves and corticospinal tract. This presents as diplopia, ipsilateral facial palsy, ipsilateral loss of corneal reflex, contralateral hemiparesis.

Option D: Dejerine-Roussy syndrome is associated with hemisensory loss and severe burning pain in the affected region. It is also known as thalamic pain syndrome.

questions.text: The parvocellular pathway from the lateral geniculate body (LGB) to the visual cortex carries signals for the detection of ______.

choices.text: Colour vision, shape, and fine details

questions.solution:
Parvocellular pathway

  • From layers 3, 4, 5, and 6 of the lateral geniculate body (LGB)
  • Gives signals for color vision, texture, shape, and fine details
  • To layer 4 of the visual cortex

Magnocellular pathway

  • From layers 1 and 2 of LGB
  • Gives signals for movement, depth, flicker, and spatial organization
  • To layer 4 of the visual cortex

Interlaminar pathway

  • Gives signals for color vision to layers 2 and 3 of the visual cortex having clusters of cells called blobs.

Image: Visual representation of the parvocellular and magnocellular pathways

questions.text: The following x-ray was done on a patient with pulmonary tuberculosis. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Golden’s S-sign is seen on the given x-ray pointing to a diagnosis of right upper lobe collapse. 

X-ray showing Golden’s S-sign and calcified breast implants.:

Golden’s S-sign/reverse S-sign of Golden is named because it resembles a reverse S shape. It can be seen on PA chest radiographs and on CT scans in right upper lobe collapse. 

S-sign can be seen in: 

  • Right upper lobe collapse
  • Bronchogenic carcinoma 
  • Primary mediastinal tumour
  • Enlarged lymph nodes
  • Lung metastasis

questions.text: All of the following enzymes are present in the mitochondrial matrix, except for ___________.
questions.solution:
ATP synthase is located on the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Note: In contrast to the other enzymes of citric acid cycle, succinate dehydrogenase is bound to the inner surface of inner mitochondrial membrane.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital with a fever and cough. She has a history of repeated chest infections for several years and coughs up yellow-green purulent sputum with some streaky hemoptysis. What could be the underlying condition based on the CT given below?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the CT showing signet ring sign is suggestive of bronchiectasis which can be due to cystic fibrosis.

A history of repeated chest infections is an indication of cystic fibrosis and a major risk factor for the development of bronchiectasis.

questions.text: A child in your unit is admitted with acute bronchiolitis. Which of the following is the most common etiological agent responsible for this condition during infancy?
questions.solution:
Acute bronchiolitis is predominantly a viral disease in children younger than 2 years. Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is responsible for more than 50% of cases.

Acute bronchiolitis refers to airway inflammation and obstruction of the lower respiratory tract. Commonly, symptoms of bronchiolitis begin with rhinitis or congestion and cough and may progress to signs of increasing respiratory distress (tachypnea, wheezing, and accessory muscle use). Management is mainly conservative.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs should not be continued on the day of surgery?
questions.solution: Oral hypoglycemic agents are generally withheld on the day of surgery except for minor, short procedures.

questions.text: A doctor tells a 31-year-old woman, who is 20 weeks pregnant, that her baby has a developmental defect. She has come to you for a second opinion. The following USG finding is seen. Identify the defect.
questions.solution:
The given ultrasound image shows an open defect in the calvaria and skin leading to the exposure of the cranial neural tube. This is consistent with the diagnosis of anencephaly. 

Anencephaly results from incomplete closure of the neural tube. It is one of the earliest detectable congenital defects that can be detected as early as 10 to 11 weeks of gestation.  Screening can also be done by serum estimation of maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP). The following are the radiological signs seen in anencephaly. 

  • Frog eye sign - Absence of cranial calvaria, prominent orbits thereby resembling the face of a frog. 
  • Shower cap sign - The absence of the cranium could lead to the protrusion of a disorganized mass of brain tissue. This resembles a shower cap giving rise to a characteristic triangular facial appearance.

Neural-tube defects can be prevented with pre-conceptional supplementation of folic acid. A dose of 4 mg daily is recommended in subsequent pregnancies.  

Other options:

Option B: Omphalocele is a midline anterior abdominal wall defect through which the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel may herniate. The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac. Given below is an ultrasound image of the fetus suggestive of an omphalocele (asterix).

Option C: Cystic hygroma is a congenital multiloculated lymphatic lesion that is classically found in the left posterior triangle of the neck. It occurs as a result of sequestration or obstruction of developing lymph vessels. This defect can be picked up in a first-trimester ultrasound. The images below show cystic hygroma on the neck of a newborn and in the fetus respectively.

Option D: Encephalocele is caused due to defects in the skull through which the meninges and/or neural tissue herniate. The squamous part of the occipital bone is the most frequently affected bone. 

The image shows a newborn with encephalocele.

questions.text: What does this barium swallow picture shows?
questions.solution:
This is a barium swallow showing a pharyngeal pouch.

Pharyngeal pouch or Zenker's diverticulum is a protrusion of the mucosa through Killian's dehiscence- a weak area of the posterior pharyngeal wall between the oblique fibers of the thyropharyngeus and the cricopharyngeus. It presents at around 60 years of age and is more common in men than women. The patients usually experience regurgitation of undigested food and recurrent cough. The diagnosis is usually made by a lateral barium swallow or by endoscopy.

The treatment is either endoscopic or open surgery. The endoscopic treatment of Zenker's diverticulum is also called as the Dohlman technique.

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

  • Hypopharyngeal diverticulum
  • False diverticulum
  • Pulsion diverticulum
  • Acquired diverticulum, seen in the elderly (>60 years)
  • Herniation is through the Killian’s triangle (a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor) in the posterior pharyngeal wall
  • Clinical features:
    • Dysphagia
    • Regurgitation
    • Halitosis
    • Aspiration
    • Gurgling sound during swallowing
  • Investigation of choice: Barium swallow (Lateral X rays)
  • Treatment
    • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
    • Surgical diverticulectomy
    • Marsupialization
    • Dohlman’s procedure

Zenker’s diverticulum

questions.text:
A 32-year-old lady underwent copper-T IUCD insertion 2 months after the delivery of her baby. A few weeks after the procedure, she presented with pain abdomen. The tail of the IUCD is not visible. Her radiograph is shown in the image below. The most appropriate step in the management of this patient is?

IUCD: Intrauterine contraceptive device
questions.solution:
The given radiograph shows the IUCD outside the uterine cavity, most likely due to perforation. The most appropriate step in the management of this patient is the removal of the IUCD by laparotomy. 

The tail of the IUCD is not visible when the IUCD is misplaced. The reasons for misplaced IUCD include:

  • Enlargement of the uterus due to pregnancy
  • Curling of the threads inside the uterus
  • Perforation of the uterus
  • IUCD buried in the myometrium
  • Spontaneous expulsion

A plain X-ray or pelvic ultrasound is used in the localization of the IUCD when the IUCD threads cannot be visualized. In this patient, the misplaced IUCD is seen laterally displaced in the pelvic cavity. An abnormal location or abnormal shape of IUCD indicates likely perforation of the uterus. 

Perforation can occur either at the time of insertion (immediate traumatic perforation) or due to gradual erosion of the myometrium (secondary perforation). The risk factors for uterine perforation include:

  • Insertion by less experienced clinicians
  • Post-partum insertion (<6 months since delivery)
  • A higher number of previous abortions
  • Lower parity
  • Lactation

Management:

If the location of the IUCD is inside the uterine cavity, it can be removed using Shirodkar's hook (Option A), a curette, or a hysteroscope (option B) and ultrasound guidance.

In perforation of the uterus, a laparotomy is done as copper-T gets adhered to the omentum or gut and will be difficult to be removed using a laparoscope.

Other options:

Option A- Spontaneous expulsion is one of the reasons for misplaced IUCD. It is not a management approach. The factors that are associated with an increased risk of spontaneous expulsion of the IUCD are age <20 years and nulliparity. Expulsion tends to occur at the time of menstruation and is associated with cramping, bleeding, and vaginal discharge.

Here the IUCD has caused perforation of the uterus and is lodged outside the uterus, hence, spontaneous expulsion will not be possible.

questions.text: Which is the most common type of dislocation of the hip?
questions.solution:
The posterior dislocation is the most common type of dislocation of hip.

 There are three main types of dislocations of the hip:

  • Posterior- It is seen in motor vehicle accidents where the flexed knee of the passenger hits the dashboard. 
  • Anterior- It is seen in high energy injuries. Eg. when the patient falls from the height.
  • Central- It is seen when there is a blow over the greater trochanter or fall on the side.

questions.text: In a 7-year-old child with hearing loss and intellectual disability, you notice the following external ear anomaly. What could the anomaly in this case be?
questions.solution:
The external ear anomaly seen here is pre-auricular tag/appendage. 

Pre-auricular tags/appendages are congenital external ear anomalies. They are seen as skin-covered pieces of cartilage anywhere between the tragus and the angle of the mouth. 

The clinical features of facial asymmetry, intellectual disability, limbal dermoid, and pre-auricular tags and mixed or conductive hearing loss point to a diagnosis of Goldenhar syndrome (oculoauriculovertebral spectrum). Clinical features include:

  1. Hypoplasia of the malar, maxillary, and mandibular regions
  2. Macrostomia and microtia
  3. Preauricular and facial skin tags
  4. Hemivertebrae (usually cervical)
  5. Intellectual disability
  6. Cardiac, renal, and central nervous system (CNS) anomalies
  7. Ocular features- Limbal dermoids, upper lid notching or coloboma, microphthalmos, disc coloboma

questions.text: Which drug should be withheld before a session of Electro convulsive Therapy?
questions.solution:
Lithium should be withheld before a session of ECT. Lithium combined with ECT has been shown to cause prolonged seizures(lasting more than 180 secs) and increased post ictal delirium. Doses are withheld for 24 hours prior to treatment, allowing for washout.

Other medications to be withdrawn before ECT:

  • Benzodiazepines 
  • Clozapine 
  • Buproprion 
  • Theophylline 
  • Reserpine

questions.text: Identify the morphology of the lesion shown in the image.
questions.solution:
The given image shows lichenification. Lichenification is a secondary skin lesion characterized by hyperpigmentation, thickening of the skin, and exaggerated skin markings. It is a feature of chronic eczema.

Related Pearl: Glossary of important skin lesions

Glossary of Important Skin Lesions

Lesion

Description

Alopecia

Absence of hair from a normally hairy area

Aphtha

A small ulcer of the mucosa

Atrophy

Loss of tissue from one or more of the epidermis, dermis or subcutaneous tissues

Burrow

A small tunnel in the skin that houses a parasite, such as the scabies acarus

Callus

A localized hyperplasia of the stratum corneum

Cellulitis

An inflammation of cellular tissue, particularly purulent inflammation of the deep dermis and subcutaneous tissue

Comedo

A plug of keratin and sebum in a dilated pilosebaceous orifice

Crusts (scabs)

Crusts consist of dried serum and other exudates

Cyst

Any closed cavity or sac (normal or abnormal) with an epithelial, endothelial or membranous lining and containing fluid or semi‐solid material

Ecchymosis

A macular area of hemorrhage more than 1 cm (bruise) in diameter

Erosion

A loss of epidermis, which heals without scarring. It commonly follows a blister.

Erythema

Redness of the skin produced by vascular congestion or increased perfusion

Excoriation

Loss of skin substance, specifically produced by scratching

Exfoliation

The splitting off of the epidermal keratin in scales or sheets

Fibrosis

The formation of excessive fibrous tissue

Fissure

Any linear gap or slit in the skin surface

Fistula

An abnormal passage from a deep structure, such as a hollow viscus, to the skin surface or between two structures

Gangrene

Death of tissue, usually due to loss of blood supply

Guttate lesions

Small round or oval lesions distributed as a ‘shower’ of droplets. Usually applied to a form of psoriasis

Haematoma

A localized tumour‐like collection of blood

Keratoderma

A horny thickening of the skin

Lichenification

Thickening of the epidermis (and to some extent also of the dermis) in response to prolonged rubbing

Macule

A flat circumscribed, non‐palpable lesion that differs in colour from the surrounding skin. It can be of any colour or shape. A macule is <1 cm in diameter, larger lesions are a patch.

Maculopapular

Rash consisting of both macules and papules

Milium

A tiny white cyst containing lamellated keratin

Nodule*

A solid palpable lesion in the dermis or subcutis, which can be observed as an elevation or can be palpated. It is >0.5 cm in diameter.

Papule

An elevated solid lesion that is < 1cm in diameter.

Petechia

A punctate haemorrhagic spot, approximately 1–2 mm in diameter.

Plaque

An elevated circumscribed lesion > 1 cm diameter; its surface is usually flat. Plaques may form from coalesced papules.

Poikiloderma

The association of cutaneous pigmentation, and telangiectasia.

Pustule

A circumscribed lesion that contains purulent material. 

Pyoderma

Any purulent skin disease

Scale

Scale is a flat plate or flake-like lesion desquamated of stratum corneum.

Scar

Replacement by fibrous tissue of another tissue that has been destroyed by injury or disease

An atrophic scar is thin and wrinkled.

A hypertrophic scar is elevated, with excessive growth of fibrous tissue.

Sclerosis

Diffuse or circumscribed induration of the subcutaneous tissues. It may also involve the dermis, when the overlying epidermis may be atrophic. It is characteristically seen in scleroderma.

Sinus

A cavity or track with a blind ending

Target lesions

These are <3 cm in diameter and have three or more zones, usually a central area of dusky erythema or purpura, a middle paler zone of oedema, and an outer ring of erythema with a well‐defined edge.

Tumour

Literally a swelling; the term is used to imply enlargement of the tissues by normal or pathological material, or cells that form a mass. 

Ulcer (of skin)

A loss of dermis and epidermis, often with loss of the underlying tissues
Vesicles and Bullae

 A vesicle is a circumscribed elevation <0.5cm in diameter that contains fluid

Bullae are >0.5 cm in diameter 
Wheal  A transient elevation of the skin due to dermal and hypodermal, often pale centrally with an erythematous rim; it is the characteristic lesion of urticaria.

 *While Rook's textbook of Dermatology,9th edition mention nodule as >0.5cm. Some authors define nodules as >1cm.

questions.text: In a boys hostel, there has been an outbreak of typhoid. The hostel cook is identified as the carrier of the disease. Which is true among the following statements regarding her condition?

choices.text: Gallbladder is usually not involved in carrier state
Chronic carriers are those who excrete the bacilli for more than a year
Tetracycline is the drug of choice for carriers
To treat the carrier state, treatment should be given for 4 weeks

questions.solution:
Chronic carriers of typhoid are those who excrete the bacilli for more than a year.

Convalescent carriers excrete bacilli for 6-8 weeks and chronic carriers excrete for more than a year. The carrier rate in females is higher. Gallbladder and biliary tract are affected. 

To treat the carrier state, an intensive course of ampicillin or amoxicillin (4-6 g a day) together with Probenecid (2 g/day) for 6 weeks is given. Cholecystectomy with concomitant ampicillin therapy is the most successful treatment for the carrier state.

questions.text: PCR is used to _____

choices.text: Seal the cut ends of DNA

questions.solution: The polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is a biochemical technology in molecular biology which is used for amplification of a single or a few copies of a piece of DNA, which leads to generation of  thousands to millions of copies of a particular DNA sequence.
